title.narrative: We are able! Ethiopia

description.narrative: By 2025, through engagement with public authorities (formal and informal powerholders), men, women and youth with disabilities and other excluded groups, through resilient and capable local CSOs/DPOs in this fragile and conflict-affected country, are successfully influencing laws, policies, practices and norms for improved food security for all.

The We are able! program targets people (including women, men, and youth) with a disability, while, as spin-off, the program will also create opportunities for other excluded groups,3 such as vulnerable women, persons affected by leprosy, youth in general, excluded ethnic groups, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, as much as possible or necessary in the specific context. Intersectional traits often make people particularly vulnerable. Refugees with disabilities or disabled women and men of particular ethnic backgrounds often face the most severe forms of food insecurity. We are able! identifies and targets groups and individuals with particular vulnerabilities while creating synergies that allow others to benefit as well.

The activities in Ethiopia are part of the We are able! program in DR Congo, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. Food security in these countries is low. People with disabilities (PWDs) are even more likely to live in food insecure households. We are able! wants to see PWDs improving their right to food and food security by creating an enabling environment for right-to-food action at grassroots level. While PWDs are the core target group of the We are able! program, we create benefits for other excluded groups like vulnerable women, youth in general, marginalised ethnic groups and internally displaced persons (IDPs), as applicable per context.

title.narrative: SCS4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
# of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association: Access to free health service at Alert Hospital for leprosy patients was interrupted due to a change of policy by the hospital leadership. However, due to continued efforts of the associations free health care for persons with leprosy has been institutionalised again. 2) FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association: Establishing a network to mobilize organisations to integrate support to persons with disabilities in their work, especially those affected by leprosy. Different organisations are participating in this network. 3) FGD 2) Kolfe Keraniyo disability association, Kolfe Keraniyo disability association, Kolfe Keraniyo, woreda 05 disability association, ECDD (Ethiopia center for disability and dev’t, Gulele disability association: Mobilization and awareness raising of persons with disabilities to actively participate in elections and to PWD to claim for their right to elect and be elected. 4) FGD 4) OSSHD, Cheshire, Association of People with Leprosy, Association of Dwarf Community session to discuss inclusion of persons with disability, raising awareness through Coffee ceremony and training. 5) FGD 5) Association of people with Leprosy, Association of Visual impaired people, Association of former army and war disabled, Association of people with hearing impairment, Association of women with disability, Association of people with physical disability: Through lobbying, targeting Government officials particularly Harari city administration, and labour and social affairs bureau to improve access to kebele houses for persons with disabilities and economically vulnerable groups. 6) FGD 5) Association of people with Leprosy, Association of Visual impaired people, Association of former army and war disabled, Association of people with hearing impairment, Association of women with disability, Association of people with physical disability: Targeting Harari city Administration, Bureau of Labour and Social Affairs and construction bureau, discussing on problems of access of building for persons with disabilities. 7) FGD 6) Gursum Wereda Labour and social affairs Bureau, Association of people with Leprosy, Hawi Association of people with physical disability, Association of Visual impaired people: Lobbying with Bureau of labour and social affairs for the Provision of wheelchairs for persons with physically and white cane for visually impaired to support independent lifestyle of persons with disabilities. 8) FGD 6) Gursum Wereda Labour and social affairs Bureau, Association of people with Leprosy, Hawi Association of people with physical disability, Association of Visual impaired people: Lobbying with Bureau of labour and social affairs for the provision of business space and start-up capital to enable persons with disabilities to run small businesses.

title.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

comment.narrative: 1) FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association: Through engagement with the Federal TEVT agency they were able to persuade them in making TEVT classrooms more accessible for persons with disabilities. 2) FGD 4) OSSHD, Cheshire, Association of People with Leprosy, Association of Dwarf: Mobilize support and create networks necessary for collective advocacy. Creating a network of the different disability associations (association of visually impaired, hearing impaired, etc.) to mobilize resources to support the supply of disability aids like wheelchairs and white canes and engaging community in selection of the beneficiaries (OSSHD).

title.narrative: SCS3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage Methodological notes
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association Targeting the general public and the school community during Leprosy days and through ‘Ewuneta’ magazine. Targeting negative perceptions of the following nature: “Persons with disabilities are beggars”, “disability is God's wrath”, “leprosy disease is an incurable disease”, “leprosy disease is hereditary”. 1) FDG 2) Kolfe Keraniyo disability association, Kolfe Keraniyo disability association, Kolfe Keraniyo, woreda 05 disability association, ECDD (Ethiopia center for disability and dev’t, Gulele disability association Targeting the general public and the school community during Leprosy days and through ‘Ewuneta’ magazine. Targeting negative perceptions of the following nature: “Persons with disabilities are beggars”, “disability is God's wrath”, “leprosy disease is an incurable disease”, “leprosy disease is hereditary”. 2) FGD 3) Association for Persons with Visual Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of the DEAF Targeting Government officials (health, education, social affairs, etc), religious leaders, and the general public using integrated approaches with other activities such as workshops, social media, etc.to adopt OPD terminology such as visually impaired rather than blind and hearing impaired rather than deaf. 3) FGD 4) OSSHD, Cheshire, Association of People with Leprosy, Association of Dwarf: Targeting Kebele leaders (= local government), youths and women associations, community polices, schools and health centres to adopt OPD terminology. 4) FGD 5) Association of people with Leprosy, Association of Visual impaired people, Association of former army and war disabled, Association of people with hearing impairment, Association of women with disability, Association of people with physical disability targeting government employees and the public through discussions and workshops to adopt OPD terminology and to avoid use offensive terminologies such as ‘handicapped’ for different persons with disability. 5) FGD 6) Gursum Wereda Labur and social affairs Bureau, Association of people with Leprosy, Hawi Association of people with physical disability, Association of Visual impaired people Targeting CSOs, Donors, Government officials (particularly labour and social affairs Office), and the community, advocating for adopting OPD terminology and providing alternatives for offensive terms such as ‘Komata’ (local term for handicapped) replaced by ‘ye siga dewe teteki’ (impairment).

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: 1) FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association: Through lobbying targeted at the Bureau of Labour and Social affairs, they succeeded in having a separate directorate created for persons with disabilities 2) FGD 3) Association for Persons with Visual Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of the DEAF Targeting Government officials (health, education, social affairs, etc), religious leaders, and the general public using integrated approaches with other activities such as workshops, social media, etc. to adopt OPD terminology such as visually impaired rather than blind and hearing impaired rather than deaf. 3) FGD 5) Association of people with Leprosy, Association of Visual impaired people, Association of former army and war disabled, Association of people with hearing impairment, Association of women with disability, Association of people with physical disability: Through Discussions with different financial institutions, these institutions have put the issue of the requirement of a driver’s license to get a loan on the agenda. For persons’ with disabilities it is sometime impossible to get a driver’s license and this automatically excludes them from the possibility of getting a loan. 4) FGD 6) Gursum Wereda Labur and social affairs Bureau, Association of people with Leprosy, Hawi Association of people with physical disability, Association of Visual impaired people Targeting CSOs, Donors, Government officials (particularly labour and social affairs Office), and the community, advocating for adopting OPD terminology and providing alternatives for offensive terms such as ‘Komata’ (local term for handicapped) replaced by ‘ye siga dewe teteki’ (impairment).

title.narrative: SCS2 # of laws, policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement.
# of laws blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association Despite widely practiced, there was no policy on adoption of persons with disability (and specifically those with leprosy). The association supported the drafting of legislation on the rights of the adoptee and it was approved and functioning these days. FGD 3) Association for Persons with Visual Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of the DEAF 1) Through lobbying tariffs and taxation levied on disability specific imported goods from abroad have been improved or lifted altogether.

title.narrative: # of governmental policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: FGD 1 ENAPAL, TLM, Birke Kibensh & friends arts enterprise, Bezuhan Saving and credit plc, Addis Ababa Leprosy association The policy that governs the creation of associations and getting finance to establish small business under the principle of cooperatives was not inclusive for persons with disability. The CSOs/OPDs published the case in newspapers which created the chance of discussion and defending the case with relevant stakeholders which led to an improvement of the policy. FGD 3) Association for Persons with Visual Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of Persons with Physical Disability, Association of the DEAF CSOs can work either on development projects or civil rights but not both. Through raising awareness at national level meetings through representative board members in Ethiopian 63 National Associations for Persons with Physical Disability they managed to improve this policy to allow combining both issues (development and human right) when it comes to persons with disability.

title.narrative: # of by-laws blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: FGD 5) Association of people with Leprosy, Association of Visual impaired people, Association of former army and war disabled, Association of people with hearing impairment, Association of women with 6disability, Association of people with physical disability 1) During COVID -19 the city administration passed a rule that limited the number of Bajaj passengers at a time within Harar city. However, persons with visual impairment need someone to accompany them. They pleaded with the Transport Bureau of Harari City administration for amendment of this rule.
